results.title: Our darkest hour
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Bee Reynolds, Will Davies and Look Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “When the war came to Australia”.
The true horror of war hits Australia as the Japanese attack and bomb Darwin. Britain’s failure to defend Singapore betrays Australia’s long held belief that the Mother Country will always come to her defence. Prime Minister John Curtin begins to rally the nation and the Americans arrive. Features reminiscences from those who lived through the experience, including Russell Braddon and Dorothy Hewett.

results.title: Our melancholy duty
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Bee Reynolds, Will Davies and Look Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “When the war came to Australia”.
Although Australians rushed to support Britain in her war with Germany, it was not until Tobruk that Australians at home really cared about the war, and not until Dunkirk that they took Hitler seriously. Mothers and wives left at home take up the traditional supporting roles and the Women’s Services are formed, but soon the daily casualty lists begin to appear and the heartbreak and dread begin. Personal recollections, rare archival footage and the music of the time combine to create an evocative and haunting picture of this unique period in Australia’s history.

results.title: Scarfies [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Robert Sarkis, Lisa Chatfield and Nightmare Productions
results.brief_description: A young group of Scarfies (local slang for students at Otago University, Dunedin) move into a squat but get more than they bargain for after discovering a crop of marijuana in the basement. Their initial exuberance gives way to panic when the owner returns for his crop. The group lock him into the basement while they figure out what to do. Starting as a light comedy, “Scarfies” shifts a gear and becomes increasingly black, resulting in a nightmarish thriller where the central characters’ morale and logic having fallen apart give way to desperate behaviour. Cast includes: Willa O’Neill, Neill Rea, Ashleigh Seagar, Taika Cohen, Charlie Bleakley, John Brazier, Mark Neilson and Mark Dudfield.

results.title: Scarface [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Brian De Palma, Martin Bregman and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: In Brian DePalma’s 1983 adaptation of “Scarface”, Al Pacino stars as Tony Montana, an exiled Cuban criminal who lands in Miami after Castro opened Mariel Harbour in 1980. Montana goes to work for a Miami drug lord (Robert Loggia), but soon rises to the top of Florida’s crime chain, appropriating Loggia’s coke-head mistress (Michelle Pfeiffer) in the process. Once having created a cocaine empire, Montana sees it crumbling at the edges as he descends into drug-induced paranoia, destroying all those who are close to him, and eventually himself. Features screenplay by Oliver Stone and music by Giorgio Moroder. Cast includes: Al Pacino, Steven Bauer, Michelle Pfeiffer, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio and Robert Loggia.

results.title: Scaramouche
results.creator_credit: George Sidney, Carey Wilson and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: This version of Rafael Sabatini’s swashbuckler stars Stewart Granger as Andre Moreau, an 18th century French nobleman who disguises himself as an actor to revenge the death of his brother at the hands of a wicked marquis. Challenged to a sword fight by the marquis, Moreau takes refuge in a theatrical troupe, posing as the clown - Scaramouche. Being in disguise provides Moreau with the time to take fencing lessons from swordmaster Doutreval (John Dehner), as well as romancing his leading lady, Lenore (Eleanor Parker). When Moreau/Scaramouche has learnt all there is to know about fencing, it’s time to face his adversary, and there are a few surprises in store too that have nothing to do with duelling. This remake credits itself as containing the longest sword fight in cinema history. Cast also includes Janet Leigh and Mel Ferrer.

results.title: Scandal = Shuban
results.brief_description: Made before Kurosawa’s breakthrough film “Rashomon”, “Scandal” is about a young painter, Ichiro, who finds himself embroiled in a scandal, when, whilst holidaying, he offers a motorbike ride to a famous singer. When two paparazzi witness this innocent outing they transform the incident into a torrid affair between the two. Outraged, Ichiro decides to sue, but the lawyer he employs - himself in a compromised situation - is easily bribed. A morality tale about the freedom of the press versus the rights of the individual, Kurosawa addresses the Americanisation of post-war Japan with his melodramatic screenplay, co-written with Ryuzo Kikushima. Beautiful black and white cinematography and impressive performances by Yoshiko Yamaguchi and Takashi Shimura.

results.title: SBS Insight: millennium bug
results.creator_credit: Tatjana Djamin and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: Just when we thought technology was under control the millennium bug fear sent shockwaves throughout the world with repercussions from PC’s to computers controlling aircraft and technical hospital equipment. The computer glitch known as the millennium bug threatened to come into being if all computers weren’t made compliant by the December 31st deadline. This episode of “Insight” looks at the crisis facing airlines and, in particular, Ansett’s strategy management of the problem. It looks at the financial cost of compliance, the formation of the millennium taskforce and the legal ramifications. Explains why technology failed us and an anthropologist, minister and historian thrash out millennium fears - which proves quite interesting in hindsight. Originally screened 28 May 1998.

results.title: Say goodbye
results.creator_credit: David H. Vowel and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description: Examines the careless arrogance by the human population toward the delicate balance of our relationship to the wildlife on earth and challenges us to rethink our role in nature.

results.title: Say a little prayer
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Lowenstein, Carol Hughes and Flying Films
results.brief_description: Richard Lowenstein’s film “Say a Little Prayer” is an under-rated Australian children’s film about a child’s perspective on the world which adults can enjoy. Eleven year old Seymour is bored during the school holidays, living with his fussy guardian in Richmond. His world changes when he meets the fabulous Angie, a young woman who treats him with respect and loving attention. They begin a friendship which is initially fun until Seymour comes to understand that his friend is a heroin user, and her life not as carefree and safe as he initially believed. Lowenstein’s gift for understanding the specificicities of subculture make this a moving film about families and contemporary dislocation. Sudi de Winter is excellent as Angie and Mickey Camilleri is the shy child Seymour. Co-stars Ben Mendelsohn. Based on Robin Klein’s novel “Came back to show you I could fly” with music by Not Drowning, Waving.

results.title: Saw sense
results.creator_credit: Jack Zalkalns, John Honey and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A chainsaw safety film aimed at both the professional and domestic user. The film is presented by a professional chainsaw operator, Robert Young, an employee of the Hobart City Council’s Mountain Maintenance gang. During a weekend firewood gathering trip, Robert takes us through the basic points of chainsaw safety.
